title-group.article-title: Heat transfer effects and topology of the viscous interaction induced by surface protuberances in hypersonic flow

abstract.p: Surface protuberances with a height of the order of the boundary layer thickness are frequently unavoidable in the design of hypersonic vehicles. These protuberances interfere with the flow and induce complex interactions which may lead to notable increases in the local surface heating rates and cause a significant damage to the vehicle. This computational and experimental study investigated hypersonic interference heating in the vicinity of simple surface protuberances. Perfect gas and Reynolds averaged Navier–Stokes simulations were carried out based on benchmark experimental cases using the compressible commercial code Cobalt. The freestream conditions were M∞ = 8.2 and Re∞/m = 9.35 × 106. The investigated protuberances were three-dimensional compression corners with different deflection angles (30°, 60°, and 90°) and with a relatively low profile where the height was approximately the same as the local boundary layer thickness. A comparison between numerical and experimental data shows a reasonable agreement, although there are areas where there are notable differences between the predictions and measurements. In the low-deflection case (30°), good agreement is observed and the location of the hot spot is well predicted by the different turbulence models. In the higher deflection cases (60° and 90°), in which the incoming boundary layer is separated ahead of the protuberance, the maximum heating rates are reasonably well predicted by the shear stress transport and k–ω models, but systematically overpredicted by the Spalart–Allmaras model. In terms of flow structure, the simulations enable a good understanding of the flow topology, which is marked by the occurrence of junction and separation vortices to the sides and upstream of the protuberance.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: The strong aerodynamic heating that occurs at hypersonic velocity generally results in high temperatures that dominate the design of hypersonic vehicles [1]. Special consideration has typically been paid to the heating of the vehicle forebody where the stagnation of the flow results in very high heat transfer rates to the surface. High heating can also take place close to surface protuberances where complex viscous interactions are induced [2]. Small surface protuberances are frequently present on hypersonic vehicles due to items such as instrumentation sensors, hinges, or thermal expansion gaps. The associated heat transfer rates to the surface in the vicinity of such protuberances constitute one of the principal concerns regarding the safety of hypersonic vehicles [3, 4]. Being able to predict the heat flux in such locations is therefore of high importance.

The effect of a surface protuberance in hypersonic flow depends mainly on its geometry (height h, width W, diameter Ø, etc.) and on the freestream flow conditions (incoming boundary layer, Reynolds number, Mach number, etc.). According to Nestler [5], three different types of protuberance geometries can be distinguished: tall protuberances (h > 2Ø orh > 2 W), short protuberances (h < Ø or h < W), and wide protuberances (Ø→∞ or W→∞, i.e. quasi-two-dimensional (2D)). Depending on the protuberance geometry, the following effects on the peak heat transfer can be expected [6].
Tall protuberances (h > 2Ø or h > 2 W): the peak heat flux is independent of protuberance height. There is no clear effect of protuberance width.
Short protuberances (h < Ø or h < W): the peak heat flux is independent of protuberance width but it increases with protuberance height.
Wide protuberances (Ø→∞ or W→∞).
As for short protuberances, the magnitude of the peak heat flux is strongly dependent on protuberance height.

In the context of this article, wedges and steps are considered as 2D geometries and protuberances 3D surface-mounted shapes with a finite span. The complexity of the flow fields generated by discontinuities in the surface curvature, and particularly by protuberances, is such that no general approach is available for theoretical predictions. Recent assessments of the capability of computational fluid dynamics (CFD) to predict similar interactions have highlighted the particular complexity in predicting such phenomena and the need for further CFD developments as well as for further experimental data [7]. Such studies have focused on benchmark interactions caused by a shock wave impinging on a surface boundary layer [8] and have found significant differences between the CFD solutions and the experimental data [9]. Where separation is present, the problem is further complicated by the unsteady nature of the flow which results in perturbations to the convective heat transfer rates [10]. Nonetheless, DeBonis et al. [7] concluded that Reynolds-averaged Navier–Stokes (RANS) methods currently provide results with an accuracy that is similar to those obtained with unsteady Navier–Stokes methods in the prediction of such benchmark interactions, except in the prediction of normal stresses where RANS methods were found to be less accurate [7]. In this study, 3D protuberances with finite span and a height of the order of the boundary layer thickness are considered from an experimental and a numerical RANS approach. According to the aforementioned classification of Nestler [5], the protuberances considered in this study are short protuberances.

The objectives of this research are to study by experimental and numerical methods the local heat transfer in the vicinity of surface protuberances, to gain some insight into the complex, 3D flow field and, finally, to analyse the suitability of a steady RANS approach to predict hypersonic heat transfer for such configurations. To achieve these aims, a CFD study has been performed using the compressible commercial code Cobalt [11] and an experimental campaign has been carried out in the Cranfield University Hypersonic Gun Tunnel. Two-dimensional validation test cases are presented before considering the more complex cases of the 3D protuberances. As part of the CFD studies, the performance of three different turbulence models is investigated: Menter's shear stress transport (SST) [12], Wilcox's 1998 k–ω [13], and the Spalart–Allmaras (SA) [14] models.

sec.title: 2.1 Introduction
sec.p:
An experimental programme was performed in the Cranfield University Hypersonic Gun Tunnel to investigate the interaction induced by surface protuberances in hypersonic flow. The freestream Reynolds number was Re∞/m = 9.35 × 106 and the freestream Mach number M∞ = 8.2 (Table 1). The initial wall temperature was 295 ± 5 K. Table 1
Experimental test conditions

sec.title: 2.2 Set-up
sec.p:
A range of protuberances were attached to a flat plate model (Figs 1 and 2). To ensure turbulent conditions, the flat plate boundary layer was tripped using a row of delta-shaped vortex generators located at 20 mm from the leading edge (Fig. 1). The investigation measured the surface heat flux at different locations in the vicinity of the protuberance. The investigated protuberances were 3D compression corners with different deflection angles (α = 30°, 60°, and 90°), finite span (W = 13.5 mm), different heights (h = 5, 10 mm), and fixed length (l = 80 mm) (Fig. 2). The undisturbed turbulent boundary layer thickness δu at the protuberance leading edge was estimated to be 5 ± 0.5 mm based on digital image processing of the schlieren pictures [15, 16]. The ratio h/δu was 1 and the ratio W/δu was 2.7. The effect of protuberance height was examined for the α = 30° configuration (Fig. 2) with a ratio h/δu of both 1.0 and 2.0. Thin-film gauges mounted on the flat plate were used to measure the wall heat transfer. Fig. 1
Plan view of experimental arrangement Fig. 2
Side view of the protuberances – deflection angle α ranging from 30° to 90° (dimensions in mm)

Measurements were performed as close as 1.5 mm (x/δu = −0.3) ahead of the protuberance and the axial distance between two gauges ranged from 2 to 4 mm (x/δu = 0.4 to 0.8), depending on the location relative to the protuberance. Measurements to the side of the protuberance were performed at 8 and 12 mm from the centre-line (i.e. 1.25 and 5.25 mm from the protuberance sidewall) which corresponds to y/δu = 0.25 and 1.05 from the protuberance side (Fig. 1).

sec.title: 2.3 Measurement uncertainty
sec.p: In the framework of the present measurements, systematic, statistical, and repeatability errors were considered and a total combined uncertainty of ±10 per cent in the measurement of Stanton number was estimated [17]. Such uncertainty is similar to the error range achieved in other similar experimental studies [18].

sec.title: 3.1 Introduction
sec.p: This numerical study considers only turbulent flows. Menter's SST k–ω [12] and Wilcox's 1998 k–ω turbulence models [13] were identified as the most suitable models for the present simulations, given the importance of the expected flow separation regions. As there was also a desire to assess the capability of a more simple turbulence model formulation to predict complex 3D flows, the SA one-equation model was also used [14]. It must be noted that although turbulence models are generally reliable for hypersonic attached flows [19, 20], such as flat plates or cones, the computation of turbulent, separated flows is still an area of research activity [19, 21, 22]. The numerical study focused on the analysis of the influence of the deflection angle by considering only the 30°, 60°, and 90° protuberances with a height (h) of 5 mm.

All 3D numerical simulations relative to the protuberances were carried out with the commercial code Cobalt [11]. Cobalt is a parallel, implicit, unstructured, compressible Euler/Navier–Stokes flow solver that uses a cell-centred finite volume approach [23]. Sutherland's law was used to calculate the dynamic viscosity from the temperature. The thermal conductivity coefficient (k) was calculated based on the viscosity and the Prandtl number (Pr), which was assumed to be constant. Although Prandtl number varies with temperature it is relatively constant in the range 300–1500 K and for this study, it was set as 0.72. Since this study is concerned with boundary layer temperatures mainly less than 1000 K, real gas effects are not expected to be significant [1]. Hence, the assumption of a calorically perfect gas model for the simulations is reasonable.

sec.title: 3.2 Algorithm
sec.p: The kernel of Cobalt is Godunov's first-order accurate, the exact Riemann method with the second-order spatial and temporal accuracies, the implicit time stepping, the viscous terms, and turbulence models being built upon this core procedure [23].

The development of the flow solution algorithm comprises the construction of initial conditions for the Riemann problem at any given cell face, solution of this Riemann problem, construction of viscous fluxes at any given face, time integration and boundary conditions.

sec.title: 3.2.1 Initial conditions for the Riemann problem
sec.p: A constant data distribution in each cell is assumed for first-order spatial accuracy. In that case, the initial conditions for the Riemann problem, the so-called left and right states, are simply the cell-centroid values of the cells to the left and right of a given face.

For second-order spatial accuracy, a linear data variation is assumed within each cell. The left initial state for the Riemann problem at face J is then (1) where q=[ρ,u,v,w,p]T is the vector of primitive variables, qi J the estimated value at the centroid of face J, due to cell i, ∇→qi the gradient vector for cell i, and r→i J the vector from the centroid of cell i to the centroid of face J. The right initial state is found similarly. The gradient vector for cell i is found by a least-squares solution to equation (1) [23]. Replacing the unknown value at the face centroid with the known value at the centroid of cell j and then considering all the nearest neighbour cells of cell i yields a matrix relation, which is solved by a QR factorization which is chosen for its good stability on high aspect ratio (AR) viscous meshes. Constructing the gradient then requires only a matrix–vector multiplication. This approach leads to an ‘upwind-biased’ second-order method (Fromm's scheme, see Hirsch [24]). However, the face centroid values given by equation (1) must be limited, in general, so as to be non-extremal with respect to the values in the two cells sharing face J. The fundamental idea behind the limiting procedure is to switch to one-sided differencing in regions of local extrema, resulting in a ‘fully-upwind’ second-order method [23]. In fact, the left and right values of a given fluid quantity are computed for every face in the grid using Fromm's scheme. If a local extremum is produced at face J for instance, the value at face J is recomputed using the fully upwind scheme. Finally, if the recomputed fluid quantity remains extremal, it is limited.

Although the procedure used by Strang et al. [23] is slightly reminiscent of the essentially non-oscillatory method [25], it is clearly a total variation diminishing method. A modified version of the exact Riemann solver of Gottlieb and Groth [26] is used to compute a unique solution given the above discontinuous initial conditions [27].

sec.title: 3.2.2 Viscous fluxes
sec.p: The formulation of the viscous terms is required to possess two main attributes: it must be conservative and it must satisfy the discrete maximum principle [23]. One possible discrete representation of ∇→·∇→q is (2) where Li is the set of cells used to construct ∇→·∇→q for the given cell i. This set is not necessarily restricted to the set of nearest neighbours, although for reasons of compactness, it is desirable to keep Li as small as possible. The discrete maximum principle requires Wj⩾0 ∀j, where the Wj's are the weights of the cells used to construct ∇→·∇→q. A third desirable attribute for the formulation of the viscous terms is that the null result be returned when ∇→·∇→q is applied to a linear field.

Conservation is easily satisfied by constructing viscous fluxes for each face and ensuring those fluxes are applied to both cells sharing the face. Hence (3) where ∇→qM is the gradient at the Mth face bounding cell i. Simultaneously satisfying the second and third attributes, however, is more difficult. The gradient at any given face of cell i can be cast as the vector sum of the normal and tangential components (4)

It is the formulation of the normal component that determines whether or not the discrete maximum principle is satisfied. Thus, it is possible to construct the tangential component of the gradient vector at a face as the average of the tangential components of the gradients in the two cells sharing the face. This tangential component can then be used in the evaluation of the normal compnent. This leads to a formulation that is essentially linearity preserving (∇→·∇→q=0 for linear q) and positive (Wj⩾0).

First-order temporal accuracy is used in this study. Analytical inviscid and viscous flux Jacobians are used [27]. The matrix equation (10) is iteratively solved with a symmetric Gauss–Seidel procedure. To improve the convergence properties of the method, the cells are reordered using the Cuthill–McKee method to reduce the bandwidth of the LHS.

sec.title: 3.3 Boundary conditions and modelling approach
sec.p:
The CFD domain is a rectangular cuboid with the flat plate as one of the rectangular faces and the protuberances mounted on the flat plate surface (Fig. 3). The boundary conditions for both the inflow and outflow faces were ‘farfield’ based on the modified Riemann invariant method. The following parameters were prescribed at the inflow: freestream Mach number, static pressure, static temperature, angle of attack, angle of sideslip, and turbulence properties. The turbulence properties were determined according to Spalart and Rumsey [28] by considering a freestream turbulence intensity of 0.1 per cent. Given the supersonic nature of the flow, no conditions were prescribed at the outflow. The flat plate and the protuberance surfaces were considered as isothermal no-slip walls and the sides and top of the domain were enforced to be symmetry planes. The main geometric simplification in creating the numerical models is that the flat plate leading edge was not modelled. However, this is in general a reasonable approach for sharp flat plates such as the one used in the experiments, where the leading edge radius was R = 0.0125 mm. Fig. 3
Boundary conditions

In viscous flows, the boundary layer generally plays a major role in terms of skin friction and heat transfer. The length of the computational domain for all the predictions was set to 350 mm to enable the growth of the flat plate boundary layer as well as the prediction of the undisturbed heat transfer characteristics. The boundary layer thicknesses obtained at the protuberance leading edge for the SA, k–ω, and SST turbulence models were 6.6 ± 0.25, 5.2 ± 0.25, and 5.3 ± 0.25 mm, respectively. Although the boundary layer thickness for the SA model is 27 per cent thicker than the other models, the predicted boundary layer for the principal cases of interests (SST and k–ω) are in good agreement with the experimental conditions (section 2.2). The results relative to the SA model, although not totally representative of the experimental conditions, are included for comparison.

sec.title: 3.4 Mesh
sec.p:
Fully structured (hexahedral cells) multi-block meshes were created for each of the protuberance configurations. To limit the computational time, a symmetry boundary condition was used along the longitudinal symmetry plane (x–z) of the protuberances (Figs 3 and 4). To get an acceptable spatial resolution to resolve sufficiently the boundary layer and the separation regions and to obtain accurate heat transfer results, approximately 5.5 million cells were used for the semi-protuberance domain. All simulations carried out in this study have resolved the viscous sublayer and no wall functions were used. Indeed, wall functions are generally not reliable for complex 3D flows which feature large separation regions. All meshes were checked in terms of general appearance (uniformity, refinement, etc.) and quality metrics (size ratio, Jacobian ratio, etc.). The surface tessellation for the 60° protuberance mesh is shown in Fig. 4. Fig. 4
Surface tessellation near the leading edge of the 60° protuberance

For the protuberance cases, a y+ sensitivity analysis showed that an appropriate value for the height of the first row was y1 = 10−7 m. Indeed, by decreasing progressively the y1 value from 10−4 to 10−7 m, it was shown that the variation in terms of flat plate peak heat transfer progressively decreased with a variation of less than 5 per cent when y1 was reduced from 10−6 to 10−7 m. This led to y+ values smaller than 0.2, which is considered to be low enough to resolve the thermal boundary layer [29, 30].

sec.title: 3.5 Grid convergence
sec.p: A grid convergence study was performed based on the 90° protuberance case, which is probably the most critical one in terms of grid convergence as this is the configuration where the strongest flow gradients occur. Three grids of approximately 3.1, 5.3, and 9.2 million cells were used for the grid convergence investigation, using a grid refinement ratio r = 1.2 in all three grid directions. The convergence was assessed in terms of total friction force in the x-direction (Fxf) and of integral heat transfer (Q) following the recommendations of Roache [31].

The relative error between the estimation of the exact continuum value and the medium grid solution is presented in Table 2 and is below 0.85 per cent, which is satisfactory. Table 2

Given the geometry of the protuberances, it is known that the flow field will feature vortices both ahead of and adjacent to the protuberances. With regard to predicting these types of vortices, conventional CFD methods require a large number of points across the vortex and along the vortex path to avoid dissipating and distorting the vortex as it is convected downstream and away from the body [32]. Higher order methods, which have lower numerical dissipation than the traditional second- or third-order spatial methods, are generally recommended [33]. However, the present simulations were limited to a second-order space discretization method, which is the highest order method available in the solver. The vortex behaviour over a relatively small area is of interest and the mesh is focused in these regions where the vortical structures arise. Furthermore, the grid convergence study shows that the integral heat transfer parameter as well as the location of the hot spot and the heat flux magnitude at this position do not change significantly between the coarse and fine grids. A variation of less than 0.3 per cent is observed in the case of the integral heat transfer between the coarse and fine grids. In terms of the local heat flux magnitude and the location of the hot spot, a variation of 5 per cent in magnitude is observed between the two grids and is associated with a 0.15 mm absolute distance in terms of change of location of the hot spot. The vortical structures are thus considered to be sufficiently resolved in this near-field region, where the results are obtained.

sec.title: 3.6 Iterative convergence
sec.p: Iterative convergence was checked in terms of theevolution of the main parameters of interest, including integral heat transfer, total friction force in the x-direction, number of supersonic cells, non-dimensional wall distance y+, as well as the temporal derivatives of density and specific dissipation rate for the full flow field. Satisfactory iterative convergence was found for all configurations, the convergence being judged satisfactory when all the aforementioned parameters had stabilized, with less than 1 per cent variation for 500 consecutive iterations.

sec.title: 3.7 Preliminary validation test cases
sec.p: Two preliminary validation test cases were investigated: a 2D flat plate and a 2D compression wedge. The capability of the CFD method to predict hypersonic heat transfer for simple configurations was initially assessed based on these results.

sec.title: 3.7.1 Flat plate
sec.p:
To get some insight into the aspects of flat plate heat transfer, previous gun tunnel measurements performed at the Imperial College under forced and natural transition conditions were compared with the prediction method of Van Driest II [34] and to the current numerical simulations. Experimental data on a sharp flat plate were obtained in the Imperial College gun tunnel number 2 [35], which uses nitrogen for both the driver and test gases. Hence, for the simulations, the gas constant, the ratio of specific heats, the Prandtl number, and Sutherland's law coefficients were set to values appropriate for nitrogen. Experimental flow conditions are listed in Table 4. Unfortunately, no data on the experiment turbulence characteristics were found in the literature. Table 4

The predicted distribution of heat flux along the flatplate for both the analytical and computational methods are compared with the measurements in Fig. 5(a). Two sets of experimental data are presented: natural transition and forced transition data. Fig. 5
Two-dimensional validation test cases

The Cobalt laminar prediction and Eckert's laminar method, which is based on a significant amount of experimental data, show good agreement with each other and overall, there is reasonable agreement with the experimental data for the natural transition case in the laminar regime (Fig. 5(a)). For the turbulent configurations, the heating rates predicted by the SST model are in relatively good agreement with Van Driest prediction method and also with the turbulent heating rates relative to the natural transition data (from x ≈ 0.4 m). The forced transition data exhibits lower heating rates, probably due to the thicker boundary layer artificially generated by the vortex generators, which were used to trip the boundary layer. Nevertheless, overall there is a relatively good agreement between the different methods which highlights, for this simple attached flow configuration, the ability of the CFD technique to predict hypersonic heat transfer.

sec.title: 3.7.2 Wedge
sec.p:
A further validation test case of a 34° compression ramp was also investigated. For this case, both experimental [36] and other numerical data [30] were available. The test conditions are presented in Table 5. Table 5
Compression corner validation test conditions
M∞ P0,∞ (MPa) T0,∞ (K) Tw (K) ρ∞ (kg/m3) U∞ (m/s) Re∞/m (m−1)
9.2 64.0 1164 295 0.1366 1515 4.73 × 106

In terms of the flow physics, increasingly higher heat fluxes are observed from the origin of the wedge (x = 0) until a maximum occurs, from which the heat transfer start to decrease, leading to plateau values (Fig. 5(b)). According to Elfstrom [37], the final pressure on the wedge stabilizes close to the inviscid level.

In Fig. 5(b), the experimental data are compared to Cobalt (this study) and other numerical solutions [30]. As shown, the current predictions using Cobalt show better agreement with the measurements when compared with the other computational data. Although the current predictions overestimate the peak heat transfer levels by approximately 25 per cent, it does capture the local maximum followed by the downstream plateau. Note that the numerical heat flux computed with Cobalt is non-dimensionalized by the same undisturbed heat flux qu used to non-dimensionalize the experimental data, which means that the flat plate heating rates (prior to the wedge) are also reasonably well predicted by Cobalt. Note the large discrepancies for the kɛJL and kζ models which predict peak heating rates more than twice as high as the experimental peak. This highlights the potential difficulties that can arise in the prediction of heat transfer in hypersonic separated flows.

sec.title: 4 PROTUBERANCE INTERFERENCE HEATING
sec.p: In the following sections, the effects of surface protuberances on the local heat transfer are investigated. The test conditions were given in Table 1.

sec.title: 4.1 Flow topology
sec.p: The flow field data provided by the numerical simulations are particularly suitable to study and analyse the 3D flow fields and to help understand the experimental data. The flow topology investigations are limited to the predictions using the SST model as they were considered to be the most reliable, based on the overall results which are presented in subsequent sections.

sec.title: 4.1.1 90° protuberance
sec.p:
A schematic illustration of the basic flow topology for the 90° protuberance is shown in Fig. 6(a). This illustrates the basic arrangement of the induced shock structure and primary vortices. Figure 6(b) shows the predicted flow streamlines on the x–z symmetry plane and Fig. 6(c) the surface skin friction lines. The incoming flow separates in front of the protuberance along the primary separation line S, which passes through the saddle point S1 and reattaches on the flat plate along the primary reattachment line R (Figs 6(a) to (c)). The separation surface that emanates from the primary separation line S rolls up to create a horseshoe vortex surrounding the protuberance. From the primary reattachment line, the flow going towards the protuberance rolls up and forms the corner vortex while the flow going upstream feeds the secondary separation line SS where a secondary bubble is created. In turn, the secondary reattachment line RS feeds the primary separation line S. In the primary recirculation bubble, the flow goes in reverse direction, except in the secondary bubble, comprised between the secondary separation and reattachment lines. Fig. 6
General flow structure – 90° protuberance (flow from left to right): (a) schematic drawing of the basic flow topology; (b) streamlines on symmetry plane; and (c) skin friction lines

In the separated region, away from the flat plate, the flow rolls up and forms two embedded 3D vortices (Fig. 6(b)). Figure 6(c) also indicates the presence of a focus of separation, to which the skin friction lines spiral, and a side reattachment line, which represents the locus of reattachment along the protuberance side. It is notable that the above discussion on flow topology corresponds to what Legendre and Werlé [38] classify as obstacle-induced separation. The general flow structure just described (separation lines, saddle points, horseshoe vortex, focus, etc.) is not particular to short protuberances but is characteristic of obstacle-induced separation flows. According to Legendre and Werlé, objects such as buildings, chimneys, or submarine conning towers produce a similar flow topology.

The structure of the flow in the case of the k–ω turbulence model was very similar to the structure observed in the SST case where there are primary and secondary separation and reattachment lines, corner vortex, focus of separation, side reattachment line, etc. However, the sizes of the different regions were slightly different, as were the separation lengths (section 4.1.5). In the case of the SA model, however, the flow physics was more different as there was only a primary separation in front of the model, with no secondary separation region predicted. The size of the primary separation was also significantly smaller than the experimental one or to that predicted by the SST and k–ω models (section 4.1.5). However, the SA model also predicted the presence of the corner vortex and the focus of separation. Moreover, to the side of the protuberance, the structure of the flow observed in the SA case was relatively similar to the SST case. As further explained in section 4.1.5, Lei [39] and Nichols [32] attribute the absence of secondary separation and the reduced size of the primary separation to a much higher eddy viscosity in the core of the vortex for the SA model, which leads to an excessive dissipation of the vortex core compared to the SST or k–ω models.

sec.title: 4.1.2 60° protuberance
sec.p:
As with the 90° protuberance, the 60° case shows the presence of a corner vortex and a primary and secondary recirculation zone. However, the 60° case exhibits only one embedded vortex (Fig. 7(a)) and no focus of separation was observed to the side of the protuberance leading edge. Also, as can be seen by comparing Figs 6 and 7, there is a noticeable difference in the separation length where it is approximately 30 mm (Ls/h = 6.0) and 24 mm (Ls/h = 4.8), respectively, for the 90° and 60° cases. sec.title: 4.1.3 30° protuberance
sec.p:
In the 30° case, the flow structure is simpler, with no secondary recirculation region identified (Fig. 8). The separation region is much smaller than for the 90° or 60° cases (Figs 6 to 8) and the flow-model reattachment line is located much lower than the one observed in the two other cases. As for the 60° case, no focus of separation was observed for the 30° protuberance. A 3D view of the 30° protuberance is given in Fig. 9 and illustrates the side reattachment line, with the location of the maximum heat transfer (hot spot). Fig. 8

sec.title: 4.1.4 Shock structure
sec.p:
For all protuberances (α = 30°, 60°, and 90°), the numerical simulations show the presence of three shocks: the flat plate leading edge shock, the separation shock (section 4.2), and the shock which originates from the front face of the protuberance, where the flow impinges on the protuberance. In the separated case, it is associated with the flow reattachment, but in general, this will be referred to as the bow shock, given its characteristic shape observed in the schlieren pictures (Fig. 10). Fig. 10
Experimental schlieren pictures – turbulent, M∞ = 8.2, Re∞/m = 9.35 × 106 (flow from left to right): (a) 30° protuberance – 5 mm high; (b) 30° protuberance – 10 mm high; (c) 60° protuberance – 5 mm high; and (d) 90° protuberance – 5 mm high

Note that for the experimental 30° cases, no separation shocks were observed (Figs 10(a) and (b)). However, although the CFD solutions showed an upstream separation for the 30° configuration, it is relatively small (about 6 mm for the SST model, see Fig. 8) and the associated separation shock is weak. Note that among the three aforementioned shocks, the strongest is the bow shock, the strength of which increases with the deflection angle.

sec.title: 4.1.5 Upstream separation
sec.p:
The extent of the calculated separation region in front of the different protuberances, for the different turbulence models, is presented in Table 6, along with the experimental data. The experimental data were determined by extrapolating the separation shocks to the flat plate (section 4.2). Since no separation shocks were clearly visible in the experiments for the 30° protuberances, the separation length was set to zero. However, it cannot be excluded that a small separation region was present but just not observable in the experiment. Table 6
Separation lengths (Ls) ahead of the protuberances
Case 30° 60° 90°
SA (mm) 2.5 ± 0.25 12 ± 0.25 16 ± 0.25
SST (mm) 6.5 ± 0.25 26 ± 0.25 31.5 ± 0.25
k–ω (mm) 8.0 ± 0.25 31 ± 0.25 35 ± 0.25
Experiments (mm) 0 21.5 ± 2 28.5 ± 2

Overall, the SST model gives the best results. The separation lengths for the SST and k–ω models are generally twice as large as those predicted by the SA model. Note that similar observations were made by Lei [39], who studied the effect of RANS turbulence models on the computation of vortical flow over a wing–body configuration (delta wing). Indeed, Lei noticed that compared to the experimental data, or to the SST model, the SA model predicted too small a separation region without capturing correctly the secondary vortices. He attributed this effect to the much higher dissipation observed in the vortical structures in the case of the SA model.

Nichols [32] mentions that traditional RANS turbulence models do not perform well in the core region of a vortex because they tend to produce too much eddy viscosity which overdamps the vortex core. In particular, the formulation of the SA model implies that in the core of a vortex, where the vorticity reaches a local maximum, the eddy viscosity increases rapidly, which leads to the excessive dissipation of the vortex core. According to Nichols, the eddy viscosity from the baseline SA model must be reduced by approximately two orders of magnitude to obtain reasonable solutions in the vortex, whereas the eddy viscosity from the baseline SST model must be reduced by one order of magnitude to obtain reasonable solutions in the vortex. This underlines the differences of the SST model compared to the SA model for separated flows. In fact, as stated by Menter et al. [21], the starting point for the development of the SST model was the need for the accurate prediction of aeronautical flows with strong adverse pressure gradients and separation.

Finally, Shur et al. [40] introduced a correction for the SA turbulence model for rotating and curved flows. According to Lei [39] and Nichols [32], this correction improves the performance of the SA model for these flows. However, these aspects where not investigated in this study.

sec.title: 4.2 Interaction classification
sec.p: Snapshot schlieren images of the side view of the protuberance flow field are shown in Fig. 10. These were obtained using a high-speed schlieren system [15] which provided videos at a frame rate of 8000 images per second. As seen in the previous sections, at a low deflection angle (α = 30°), the turbulent boundary layer was mainly undisturbed ahead of the protuberance. This is confirmed by the schlieren pictures which do not show the clear presence of separation shocks for the 30° cases (Figs 10(a) and (b)). Hence, this is considered as an attached interaction. There is no discernible difference in the flow structure for the 30° case when the protuberance height is doubled from 5 to 10 mm (Figs 10(a) and (b)). However, at higher deflection angles (α = 60° and 90°), the much stronger adverse pressure gradient to which the boundary layer is exposed when approaching the protuberance results in flow separation regions (Figs 6 and 7) and the presence of separation shocks (Figs 10(c) and (d)). In these cases, the interactions are marked by the large-scale unsteadiness of the separation shock.

In the separated cases, the flow separates ahead of the protuberance and reattaches just in front of it (Figs 6 and 7). This results in locally augmented heating rates at the reattachment point ahead of the protuberance, the magnitude of which depends on the deflection angle (Figs 11(a) and 12(b)). On the other hand, attached interactions are characterized by a zone of relatively low heat transfer in front of the protuberance, due to the low skin friction of the flow which is on the verge of separation (Figs 11(a) and 12(a)). In this case, the highest heating rates, which are approximately twice as high as the undisturbed heating rates, are found to the side of the protuberance, along the side reattachment line (Fig. 9). As shown in Fig. 11, for a low deflection angle (α = 30°), the protuberance height does not have a significant impact on the heating rates. Whether the protuberance is 5 or 10 mm high (h/δu = 1 or 2), if the ramp deflection is kept equal, the oncoming flow predominately faces the same obstacle and therefore produces similar local heating rates. Fig. 11
Heat transfer measurements on the flat plate in front of and to the side of the protuberances: (a) y = 0 mm – centre-line; (b) y = 8 mm – y/δu = 0.25 from the protuberance edge Note: turbulent, M∞ = 8.2, Re∞/m = 9.35 × 106 (x and y are streamwise and spanwise coordinates) Fig. 12
Measured heat flux in the vicinity of protuberances with α = 30° and 90° (plan view): (a) α = 30° protuberance; (b) α = 90° protuberance Note: turbulent, M∞ = 8.2, Re∞/m = 9.35 × 106

sec.title: 4.3 Relation between topology and wall heat transfer
sec.p:
The link between flow topology and wall heat transfer can be understood by comparing relevant topology and heat transfer figures. This is the purpose of Fig. 13 (to be compared with Fig. 6), which shows the calculated Stanton number and skin friction coefficient distributions on the flat plate for the 90° protuberance (SST turbulence model). Along the reattachment lines, peaks in heat transfer are observed, whereas along separation lines, troughs appear (Figs 6 and 13). In general, the peaks and troughs located ahead of the protuberance (negative x in Fig. 13) are due to the flow separation and reattachment as a result of the adverse pressure gradient, whereas the peaks observed at positive x locations in Fig. 13 are due to the reattachment of the flow to the side of the protuberance (Fig. 9). Fig. 13
Calculated Stanton number and skin friction coefficient distributions on flat plate at different y locations, showing the link between flow topology and peaks and troughs in heat transfer data (α = 90°): (a) y = 0 mm – St; (b) y = 8 mm – St; (c) y = 12 mm – St; and (d) y = 8 mm – St and Cfx

However, the presence of peaks and troughs in the heat transfer distributions does not seem to be an absolute indication of flow separation or reattachment. Indeed, in the case of the SA model, secondary heat transfer peaks and troughs were observed without the presence of an associated separation. Finally, it is interesting to note the similarity between heat transfer and skin friction coefficient in the x-direction Cfx which typically forms the basis of the Reynolds analogy [34]. As shown in Fig. 13(d), in a region of reverse flow, the Cfx distribution is almost the perfect mirror image of the Stanton number, whereas in a region of forward flow, the trend exhibited by Cfx is similar to that of the Stanton number.

sec.title: 4.4 Heat transfer distribution
sec.p:
Figure 14 shows the predicted contour plots of Stanton number using the SST turbulence model. The hot regions are confined to a relatively limited area around the protuberances, particularly in the α = 30° case. In the α = 60° and 90° cases, the structure is quite similar. However, the interaction region is larger in front of the α = 90° protuberance. In both cases (α = 60° and 90°), the region located in front of the protuberance exhibits the presence of a region of relatively low heat transfer slightly ahead of the protuberance leading edge (Figs 14(b) and (c)) along with an area of high Stanton number in the region directly ahead of the protuberance. For the α = 60° case, the high heat transfer region encompasses the area immediately ahead of the leading edge as well as extending slightly around the leading edge corner (Fig. 14(b)). For the α = 90° case, the high heat flux region is primarily restricted to a small area immediately ahead of the protuberance leading edge. In the α = 30° case, a region of relatively low heat transfer is also observed in front of the protuberance which extends around to the side of the body. Fig. 14
Predicted Stanton number on the flat plate surface using the SST turbulence model: (a) α = 30° protuberance; (b) α = 60° protuberance; and c) α = 90° protuberance

sec.title: 4.5 Hot spot
sec.p: Predictions of the heat flux magnitude at the hot spot and hot spot location are analysed in this section.

sec.title: 4.5.1 Maximum heating augmentation ratio
sec.p:
The maximum heating augmentation ratios (HAR, defined as the local Stanton number normalized by the undisturbed Stanton number) for different protuberances and turbulence models are presented in Table 7 along with the experimental data. In the α = 60° and 90° cases, the predicted maximum HARs are systematically higher than the experimental ones. In the 90° case, the HAR predicted by the SA model is four times the experimental one. Except for the 30° case, where the k–ω shows better agreement with the experiments, the maximum HARs predicted by the SST model are the closest to the experimental ones. The three considered turbulence models overpredict in most cases the maximum experimental HAR. Overall, the SST model gives the best predictions while the SA model largely overpredicts the maximum HAR in the separated cases (α = 60° and 90° protuberances). Note that additional simulations carried out with the SST model for two different boundary layer thickness showed, as expected, an increase in the maximum HAR for a thinner boundary layer. This indicates that, in the case of the SA model, it is expected that, if the numerical boundary layer thickness was better matched to the experimental conditions (5 mm instead of 6.6, see sections 2.2 and 3.3), this would result in an even larger overprediction of the HARs. Table 7
Maximum HAR for different protuberance cases
Case α = 30° α = 60° α = 90°
SA 2.56 15.96 42.54
SST 2.56 7.13 16.34
k–ω 2.94 7.83 20.08
Experiments 2.9 5.4 10.9

All of the datasets clearly show that there is a notable increase in the peak surface heat flux as the protuberance wedge angle increases. The 30° configuration presents a moderate peak heat flux, with the local maximum occurring adjacent to the protuberance side. For the 60° and 90° configurations, the upstream separation plays a significant role, with the peak heat flux occurring within this upstream region, along the primary reattachment line.

sec.title: 4.5.2 Hot spot location
sec.p:
With regard to the regions of highest heating rates, Fig. 15 shows that for α = 90°, the hottest region is located in front of the protuberance. For α = 60°, the hot region extends from the front to the side of the protuberance (Figs 15(d) to (f)). Finally, for α = 30°, the hot region is exclusively located to the side of the protuberance (Figs 15(a) to (c)). The trend shown by the numerical results is thus similar to the one observed in the experiments except that in the experiments, for α = 90° and 60°, the hot spot was located on the centre-line, whereas in the simulations, the hot spot is off the centre-line. However, it is quite common in 3D separated flows to observe higher heating rates off the centre-line [41]. Fig. 15
Contour plots of predicted wall heat transfer showing hot spots as white dots: (a) 30° – SA; (b) 30° – SST; (c) 30° k–ω; (d) 60° –SA; (e) 60° – SST; (f) 60° k–ω; (g) 90° –SA; (h) 90° – SST; and (i) 90° k–ω

As shown in Figs 15(g) to (i), the location of the hot spot is relatively constant for different turbulence models for the α = 90° configuration. For the 60° protuberance, the region of high surface heat flux is more distributed and the location of the hot spot is more sensitive to the turbulence model. In front of the 90° and 60° protuberances, the hot spot is located at distances between 0.5 and 1.5 mm upstream of the leading edge, which corresponds to the primary reattachment region of the flow (Figs 6 and 7). In the experiments, the closest measurements ahead of the protuberance were made at a distance of 1.5 mm, which could partly explain the lower experimental HAR (Table 7). Regarding the 30° protuberance, the hot region is the consequence of the reattachment of the flow to the side of the protuberance (Figs 9 and 15). As with the 90° protuberance, the predicted location of the hot spot is relatively constant for different turbulence models in the α = 30° case (Figs 15(a) to (c)).

sec.title: 4.6 Comparison of numerical and experimental data
sec.p: This section presents the comparisons between the computations and the experimental data for the α = 30°, 60°, and 90° protuberances.

sec.title: 4.6.1 30° protuberance
sec.p:
Figure 16 shows the results for the α = 30° configuration for all three turbulence models (SA, k–ω, and SST) and highlights that overall, the heat transfer distributions are relatively well captured at the different spanwise locations. In this case, where the predicted separation is small, the SA model does not overpredict the HAR. As will be presented in the following sections, the behaviour of the SA model is less convincing for highly separated flows. Note that in the numerical solutions, the first troughs in heat transfer rate correspond to the primary separation line. In the experimental case, although no clear separation was observed for the α = 30 protuberance, the decreasing trend in heat flux shown in Figs 16(a) and (b) is a clear sign that an adverse pressure gradient is bringing the flow close to separation. Fig. 16
Experimental and numerical heat transfer at different y locations – 30° protuberance: (a)y = 0 mm – centre-line; (b) y = 4 mm – y/δu = 0.8 from centre-line

sec.title: 4.6.2 60° protuberance
sec.p:
For the α = 60° configuration, the flow field is characterized by a large separation region ahead of the protuberance which results in a locally high HAR due to the primary reattachment of the flow which occurs approximately 1 mm in front of the protuberance (see the highest peaks in Figs 17(a) and (b)). At y = 8 mm from the centre-line, for the negative x locations, the distribution of heat transfer is well captured by the different turbulence models, while at positive x locations all of the turbulence models overpredict the HARs (Fig. 17(c)). The heating rates to the side of the protuberance are due to the reattachment of the flow along the side reattachment line (Fig. 7). At y = 12 mm from the symmetry plane, the SA model is the only one which is reasonably able to capture the experimental plateau located approximately between x = 0 and x = 15 mm. Indeed, in that zone, the HARs predicted by the SST and k–ω models are significantly lower. From x ≈ 20 mm, the numerical HARs are higher than the experimental ones. Although the SAmodel is the only one that captures the heat transfer local maximum at this spanwise location (y = 12 mm), it also substantially overpredicts the local peak HAR values at the other locations (y = 0, 4, 8 mm) where the k–ω and SST models generally give better predictions. Fig. 17
Experimental and numerical heat transfer at different y locations – 60° protuberance: (a) y = 0 mm – centre-line; (b) y = 4 mm – y/δu = 0.8 from centre-line; (c) y = 8 mm – y/δu = 0.25 from side edge; and (d) y = 12 mm – y/δu = 1.05 from side edge

sec.title: 4.6.3 90° protuberance
sec.p:
For the α = 90° configuration, on the centre-line (y = 0 mm), the SST and k–ω turbulence models underpredict the experimental HAR, whereas the SA model overpredicts it (Fig. 18(a)). At y = 0 mm and 4 mm, the HARs predicted by the SA model are more than twice as high as those of the SST and k–ω models (Figs 18(a) and (b)). It is worth recalling that in this region, the SA model underpredicted all of the separation lengths in comparison with the measurements and with the SST and k–ω models (Table 6). The SST and k–ω models overpredict the experimental peak HAR at y = 4 mm (Fig. 18(b)). However, they still underpredict the HARs relative to the first three experimental points ahead of the protuberance. Note that the troughs present in the SST and k–ω solutions near x = −6 mm do not appear in the experimental data. In terms of maximum HARs, at y = 4 mm, they are about 10.3, 13.3, 17.9, and 38.2 in the experimental, SST, k–ω, and SA cases, respectively. Fig. 18
Experimental and numerical heat transfer at different y locations – 90° protuberance: (a) y = 0 mm – centre-line; (b) y = 4 mm – y/δu = 0.8 from centre-line; (c) y = 8 mm – y/δu = 0.25 from side edge; and (d) y = 12 mm – y/δu = 1.05 from side edge

At y = 8 mm from the centre-line, the highest HARs (near x = 0) are due to the reattachment of the flow that separates in front of the protuberance (Fig. 18(c)), whereas the lower ratios observed at positive x locations are due to the reattachment of the flow to the side of the protuberance. At y = 8 mm, the numerical data generally overpredict the experimental HARs. At y = 12 mm (Fig. 18(d)) the plateau values, particularly visible for the SST and k–ω models appear to be due to a combined effect of the front and side reattachment of the flow.

sec.title: 5 CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: A study was performed to investigate the effects of the presence of relatively small surface protuberances on the local heat transfer on a flat plate at hypersonic velocities. Numerical simulations were performed along with an experimental programme. Initial validation of the computational method was performed on relatively simple geometries (flat plate and a compression wedge). Overall, these test cases showed a fair agreement between the numerical predictions, experimental data, and engineering methods. In the more complex case of the protuberance, the agreement between the CFD and the measurements was reasonable. The trends in heat transfer distributions were generally well captured; however, in terms of absolute magnitude, relatively large discrepancies were observed for some configurations. Relatively good agreement was found between the SST and k–ω models in terms of separation length, flow topology, and local HARs. Overall, the SST model gave the best predictions, while the SA model largely overpredicted the maximum HARs in the separated cases (α = 60° and 90° protuberances).

The presence of protuberances of the size of the local boundary layer is shown to induce high heat transfer rates on the surface of the flat plate. In high-deflection geometries, the hot spot is located in front of the protuberance and is characterized by high to very high heating rates, depending on the deflection angle. On the other hand, the hot spot is found to the side of the protuberance in low-deflection configurations and the heat transfer at the hot spot remains moderate. The experimental data showed that by reducing the deflection angle from 90° to 30°, the heat transfer at the hot spot could be reduced by almost a factor of four, hence showing the necessity to avoid blunt protuberances on hypersonic vehicles.

Finally, it is important to underline the complementarity and relevance of performing both experimental and numerical work. Indeed, when they are used in conjunction, they can yield useful information that each approach on its own cannot.
